articles.headline: Professional Journalism 73% More Accurate Than Social Media
articles.summary: Fact-checking study shows value of editorial standards.
articles.content: Columbia Journalism Review found traditional outlets far more accurate. Editorial processes catch errors before publication. Journalists trained in verification methods. Legal accountability ensures responsibility. Professional standards protect truth.
articles.statementText: Traditional journalism is more reliable than citizen journalism and social media news

articles.headline: Citizen Journalists Expose Stories Mainstream Media Ignores
articles.summary: Independent reporting challenges corporate media narratives.
articles.content: Alternative media exposed government surveillance programs. Corporate media bias documented extensively. Citizen journalists provide diverse perspectives. Grassroots reporting more authentic. Traditional media serves elite interests.
articles.statementText: Traditional journalism is more reliable than citizen journalism and social media news

articles.headline: Fact-Checking Reduces False Belief Acceptance 30%
articles.summary: Studies show effectiveness of misinformation correction.
articles.content: MIT research demonstrates fact-checking changes minds. False information spread reduced significantly. Public trust improved with verification. Democracy strengthened by accurate information. Misinformation networks disrupted effectively.

articles.headline: Fact-Checkers Show Political Bias in Story Selection
articles.summary: Analysis reveals partisan patterns in verification efforts.
articles.content: Media Research Center documented bias in fact-checking. Conservative claims checked more frequently. Subjective interpretation of `facts` problematic. Fact-checkers become truth arbiters. Censorship disguised as verification.

articles.headline: Information Quality Requires Multiple Verification Sources
articles.summary: Media experts advocate critical consumption skills.
articles.content: Stanford media literacy program teaches source evaluation. No single source completely reliable. Bias exists across spectrum. Critical thinking essential for citizens. Media ecosystem requires active participation.
